verses.text: But now, thus says the LORD, who created you, O Jacob, and he who formed you, O Israel: 'Do not fear, for I have redeemed you; I have called you by name, you are mine.'
verses.comment: This verse shows God's personal relationship and ownership of His people. 'Redeemed' is used here in the context of rescue, which finds a fuller meaning in the redemption accomplished by Christ (1 Pet 1:18-19). The calling by name signifies a selection and election reminiscent of baptism, where a person is claimed by God.

verses.text: 'When you pass through the waters, I will be with you; and through the rivers, they shall not overwhelm you. When you walk through the fire, you shall not be burned, and the flame shall not consume you.'
verses.comment: God's presence protects His people in trials—an anticipation of Christ's promise to be with His Church 'to the end of the age' (Matt 28:20). The imagery recalls Israel's passing through the Red Sea and the saving of the three young men in Daniel.

verses.text: 'For I am the LORD your God, the Holy One of Israel, your Savior. I gave Egypt as your ransom, Cush and Seba in exchange for you.'
verses.comment: God identifies Himself as both Savior and 'Holy One,' foreshadowing Christ as the Holy One (Acts 3:14). The exchange imagery is a type of substitutionary redemption.

verses.text: 'Because you are precious in my eyes, honored, and I love you, I give men in exchange for you, peoples in exchange for your life.'
verses.comment: God's love is the reason for Israel's chosen status (cf. Deut 7:7-8). The phrase 'I love you' is rare in the Old Testament, highlighting the deep affection resembling the love God has for His Church.

verses.text: 'Do not fear, for I am with you; I will bring your offspring from the east, and gather you from the west.'
verses.comment: This is a promise of restoration, prefiguring the gathering of all nations into one family under God (cf. Matt 8:11, the ingathering into the Kingdom).

verses.text: 'I will say to the north, "Give up," and to the south, "Do not hold back; bring my sons from afar, and my daughters from the ends of the earth,"'
verses.comment: God commands the nations themselves to release His people, foreshadowing the spiritual calling of all people, sons and daughters together, into the unity of God's family.

verses.text: 'everyone who is called by my name, whom I created for my glory, whom I formed and made.'
verses.comment: Being 'called by my name' anticipates the new identity of God's people in Christ, who bear God's name through incorporation into the Body of Christ.

verses.text: 'Bring out the people who are blind, yet have eyes, who are deaf, yet have ears.'
verses.comment: Refers to spiritual blindness and deafness—a major theme continued by Jesus when he speaks in parables, implying the need for healing not just of the senses but of the soul.

verses.text: 'Let all the nations gather together, and let the peoples assemble. Who among them can declare this, and show us former things? Let them bring their witnesses to prove them right, and let them hear and say, "It is true."'
verses.comment: God challenges the nations to show their power through prophecy, contrasting the uniqueness of the LORD's revelation—a theme central to apologetics.

verses.text: 'You are my witnesses,' declares the LORD, 'and my servant whom I have chosen, so that you may know and believe me and understand that I am he. Before me no god was formed, nor shall there be any after me.'
verses.comment: 'I am he' is echoed by Jesus in John 8:58, where He uses 'I AM' to claim divinity. God's choice of his Servant foreshadows the perfect Servant, Christ (Isa 42:1).

verses.text: 'I, I am the LORD, and besides me there is no savior.'
verses.comment: There is only one savior, a title the New Testament gives to Christ, identifying Him with God Himself (Acts 4:12).

verses.text: 'I declared and saved and proclaimed, when there was no strange god among you; and you are my witnesses,' declares the LORD, 'that I am God.'
verses.comment: God alone acts in history for salvation, showing the exclusivity of true worship. 'My witnesses' anticipates the later mission of the Church to testify to the world.

verses.text: 'Also henceforth I am he; there is none who can deliver from my hand; I work, and who can turn it back?'
verses.comment: God's sovereignty is unchallenged—creaturely power cannot thwart His will. Parallels are seen in Daniel 4:35.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD, your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: 'For your sake I send to Babylon and bring down as fugitives all of them, even the Chaldeans, in the ships in which they rejoice.'
verses.comment: God is 'Redeemer,' pointing to salvation through judgment on Israel's enemies—a recurring theme fulfilled in Christ's final victory.

verses.text: 'I am the LORD, your Holy One, the Creator of Israel, your King.'
verses.comment: God is depicted as King, anticipating Christ as King of Kings (cf. John 18:36-37) and the close link between creation and kingship.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD, who makes a way in the sea, a path in the mighty waters,
verses.comment: Recalls the Exodus, a foundational act of salvation in the Old Testament, repeated liturgically as a pattern for later deliverance.

verses.text: 'who brings forth chariot and horse, army and warrior; they lie down, they cannot rise, they are extinguished, quenched like a wick.'
verses.comment: God's devastation of the military forces in the Exodus is a sign that only He saves, through overwhelming power.

verses.text: 'Remember not the former things, nor consider the things of old.'
verses.comment: A call to look ahead to God's new acts of salvation, ultimately fulfilled in Christ, who brings the new creation (2 Cor 5:17).

verses.text: 'Behold, I am doing a new thing; now it springs forth, do you not perceive it? I will make a way in the wilderness and rivers in the desert.'
verses.comment: Anticipates the new exodus—a theme continued in John the Baptist's ministry (Matt 3:3) and the idea of the Church as the new way.

verses.text: 'The wild beasts will honor me, the jackals and the ostriches, because I give water in the wilderness, rivers in the desert, to give drink to my people, my chosen,'
verses.comment: Even creation itself is renewed and benefits from God's mercy to His people.

verses.text: 'the people whom I formed for myself, that they might declare my praise.'
verses.comment: God's people exist for worship—a royal priesthood (1 Pet 2:9), a calling continued by the Church.

verses.text: 'Yet you did not call upon me, O Jacob; but you have been weary of me, O Israel!'
verses.comment: God notes His people's neglect, which anticipates Christ's frequent call for repentance and genuine worship.

verses.text: 'You have not brought me your sheep for burnt offerings, or honored me with your sacrifices. I have not burdened you with offerings, or wearied you with frankincense.'
verses.comment: Places the focus on the heart, not just external sacrifices—a theme fulfilled as Christ institutes the perfect sacrifice.

verses.text: 'You have not bought me sweet cane with money, or satisfied me with the fat of your sacrifices, but you have burdened me with your sins, you have wearied me with your iniquities.'
verses.comment: God desires true contrition. Sacrifices are meaningless without repentance and a contrite heart.

verses.text: 'I, I am he who blots out your transgressions for my own sake, and I will not remember your sins.'
verses.comment: God alone forgives sins, a prerogative later claimed by Christ (Mark 2:10), indicating His divine authority—a key aspect of sacramental forgiveness.

verses.text: 'Put me in remembrance; let us argue together; set forth your case, that you may be proved right.'
verses.comment: God challenges His people to reason with Him, recalling God's invitation to reconciliation and repentance.

verses.text: 'Your first father sinned, and your mediators transgressed against me.'
verses.comment: 'First father' refers to Adam or possibly Abraham; ‘mediators’ points to the priests and prophets, showing the need for a new and perfect Mediator.

verses.text: 'Therefore I profaned the princes of the sanctuary, and gave Jacob to utter destruction and Israel to reviling.'
verses.comment: The judgment includes even the religious leaders—the need for a new, holy priesthood is made clear, as fulfilled in the perfect mediation of Christ and His appointed leaders.
